chapter.p: The participants will process their translation with the help of Paratext, a program created for entering, storing, and checking the translated texts. The course follows the six stages of translation as given in the SIL plan. The first two stages were covered in an earlier manual. This manual covers stages 3-6.
At the end of the course, the participant will be able to:

p.object: Stage 3: Prepare for a consultant check

chapter.p: 1.Prepare a back translation
2.Complete other checks

ul.li: check references, quoted texts, numbering, unmatched pairs of punctuation, quotations

chapter.p: All the tasks for this step have been covered in previous modules.

ul.li: Identify the names for any maps to be included.
Add an introduction to the NT / Bible
Confirm that all the other checks have been completed.
Check numbers, money, weights and measures

chapter.p: Stage 3: Preparing for the Consultant check
In this third stage of a translation project you will do comprehension testing and back translation. You will also continue with the basic checks and spell checking.
The following modules will help you in this stage:

tr.td:
Create a new project
for the back translation
(first time only)

chapter.p: Introduction

This module explains how to draft a back translation into a separate ParaTExt project and keep it up-to-date. [The next module will explain how to do a word by word gloss of the translation using the project interlinearizer.]

You have typed, checked and revised your translation in ParaTExt and are now preparing for a consultant check. Before you can start your Administrator must have created a separate project for your back translation.

Your text needs to be check by a consultant. But because the consultant does not know your language, you need to translate your text back into a language they can understand. This is where the term back translation comes from. The consult will use this translation to help the team improve your exegetical choices in the text.

It is preferable that this is done by someone who hasn’t been involved in your translation. This way she will type what the text says and not what you meant it to say. This should also be done without looking at any helps or other Bibles.

ul.li: Open your project and back translation project
Arrange your text on the screen.
Mark the status as finished when you complete a chapter.
Check that your text is up-to-date (or in sync), view any differences by moving to the next change if appropriate.

chapter.p: Summary
This module shows you how to:

secTitle.object: Create a new project for the back translation

ul.li: Type a full name for the project and a short name
Choose the language for your back translation (e.g. English)
For the Type of project choose « Back Translation »
For Based on choose your project

section1.p: The project should not need to be registered as it inherits the registration from your project.

ul.li: Arrange the windows so that you can easily see both windows.
Click in the back translation window, (the verse in your project is highlighted).
Type your back translation into each verse (after the check box).
Continue for each verse in the chapter.

section1.p: When you have finished the chapter

ul.li: On the toolbar at the top of your back translation window, click on the arrow beside the check mark.

Choose Mark All Verses in Chapter as Finished.
All the check boxes for the chapter are marked with green checks.

secTitle.object: When a change is made to your project

section1.p: ParaTExt will detect any saved changes to your text and will change the back translation checkbox to a red question mark and add issues to the back translation status in the project plan.

ul.li: Click in a verse with the red question mark.
Review and correct the back translation.

Click the red question mark
It changes to a green check mark

secTitle.object: View the differences for outdated verses

ul.li: Click on the ab icon on the toolbar to see the differences.
Click on the up and down arrows to move to the previous or next differences.

Expand Stage 3, the back translation checks are at the end
The number of issues (if any) are displayed

secTitle.object: Back translation verse check in project plan

ul.li:
Click on the issues link
A result list window lists any errors.

secTitle.object: Back translation status complete in project plan

ul.li: The back translation window is displayed with the cursor in the first verse with problems.
Correct the problem and move to the next outdated verse by clicking on the arrows on the toolbar.

section1.p: The checkboxes in a back translation can have a number of different symbols.
Look in the ParaTExt help “What symbols can occur in status checkboxes in a back translation?” topic and match the following symbols and status:
Answers: A3, B4, C5, D1, E2

tr.td:
Create a new project for
the second back translation
(first time only)

chapter.p:
The previous module explained how to create a back translation that expresses what a reader understands when he reads or hears the text. There is another type of back translation that is sometimes used and that is a word-for-word style back translation. Some consultants may ask for this style of back translation. If you need to make one of these, you can use Paratext’s project Interlinearizer function.
Please note that in you can only use the Interlinearizer on registered projects.

You have typed, checked and revised your translation in ParaTExt and are now preparing for a consultant check. Before you can start your Administrator must have created a separate project for your word for word back translation. [This is separate from the readable back translation in the previous module.]

Your consultant needs to have a copy of your translation in a language they can understand. The back translation done in the previous module is very useful but there are times when a literal translation is more helpful.

You will use the project interlineariser to produce a word for word gloss of the text. Firstly, you will setup the interlineariser, and then correct any errors. The computer’s initial guesses are often wrong but it learns as it goes and becomes quite accurate quickly. The idea is for the gloss to be correct even though the word order is not correct. When you are happy with the verse you can export it to the back translation project.
This module shows you how to:

secTitle.object: Create a new project for the back translation

ul.li: Type a full name for the project and a short name
For the type of project choose « Back Translation »
Choose the language for your back translation (e.g. English)
Choose your project as the project it is based on

section1.blockquote: The project should not need to be registered as it inherits the registration from your project.

ul.li: Choose your project as the text to interlinearise [1]
Choose a model text in the consultant’s language: either your reference text or your second back translation project [2]
Dropdown the list and choose your second back translation project

section1.blockquote: Note: You do not need to use the Model and text are related checkbox – this is for when you are doing an adaptation (or orthography change)...

secTitle.object: Confirm and correct the interlinearised text [◙ RT02]

ul.li:
Click the incorrect gloss
A list is displayed.

Either click on the correct gloss in the list
or type the correct gloss in the textbox

section1.blockquote: Note: You do not have to confirm the correct glosses. Any glosses that are correct will be automatically confirmed when you approve and export.

ul.li: Click bin the space between two glosses

secTitle.object: Specify the morphology (break a word into morphemes) [◙ RT05]

ul.li: Click on the word in the translation line (top line)
Add spaces to separate the morphemes and add «+ » prefixes and suffixes (see guide)

secTitle.object: Approve and Export the text [◙ RT06]

ul.li: To continue, click Next Unapproved Verse

section1.p: For more help on using the Interlineariser function see:

ul.li: How do I open the Project Interlinearizer?
How do I generate an interlinear back translation?
How do I create a back translation project with the Interlinearizer?
How do I create a text revision/adaptation project with the Interlinearizer?
What do the colours of glosses mean in the Interlinearizer?

chapter.p: In this module you will learn how to run the remaining basic checks (references, quoted text, numbers, punctuation in pairs and quotations). As in the first two basic checks modules, it is easier to run the checks from the project plan. However, if you want to check more than one book then you need to run the checks from the checking menu.
You have typed your translation into ParaTExt. Make sure you have done the checks described in modules BC1 and BC2 before continuing.

ParaTExt has eleven basic checks. You have already seen the first six checks. This last set of checks help you find errors related to material refered from other books. You want to be sure the references are accurate so that the reader can find those passages.

p.object: What you are going to do

chapter.p: As before, most of the checks require some setup to be done by your administrator. In this module you will:

ul.li: Confirm that the setup has been done

chapter.p: This module shows you how to:

section1.blockquote: This check looks at punctuation that occurs in pairs (opening and closing) and lists errors where it is not matched by the other half of the pair. This may be deliberate but is more likely to be an error, e.g. ( ), [ ], etc.

ul.li:
Checking > Unmatched pairs of punctuation:
If the list is empty, then there are no errors.
If necessary, click Options... to add other pairs.

section1.blockquote: Before you can run the references check, your Administrator must define various settings.

ul.li:
For each setting, type the punctuation in the box
The sample will be updated on the right.
Fill-in the three columns [1] with abbreviation, short name and long name.
Choose Abbreviations [2] and [3] for both cross-references and references

section1.blockquote: Paratext will inform you if there are any inconsistencies between these book name settings and the \toc lines and will allow you to check conflicts.
Before you can run the references check, your Administrator must define various number settings.

section1.p: The quotations check is used to ensure you have been consistent in marking the direct speech correctly.
section1.blockquote: Before you can run the quotation check, your Administrator must define the rules for your quotations.

ul.li: Fill-in the quotation marks used for each level [1] [2] [3]

li.object: Check Flag all quotes near other errors [5]

ul.li:
Click OK.
A list of errors is displayed. It shows possible errors but includes four correct quotations before and after the possible error.
Double-click the first item which doesn’t start with
Click Rerun button to confirm you have corrected the error.

section1.blockquote: The Quoted text check looks at text in footnotes or cross-references which has been marked with \qt \qt* markers. It checks that the quoted text matches the text in the verse.

ul.li:
Click OK.
A list of errors is displayed.

section1.blockquote: Note: the text has to be exactly the same as in the text. That is, even additional punctuation can’t be in the \qt \\qt* markers.

part.p: The fourth stage of a translation project is the consultant visit. You will meet with the consultant and evaluate your text, make notes and revise your texts and back translations as needed. You will want to ensure that you have updated the status of your translation in the project plan.
All tasks in this stage have been covered in previous modules.
The fifth stage of a translation project is the review by the community. In the review you will check for naturalness, produce a team progress report and revise the key terms.
The following modules will help you in this stage:

chapter.p: In this module you will create a progress report.
As you have been working on your translation, you have been updating your project plan with your progress on completed chapters and books. Now you will project a report.
Your administrators and funders need accurate reports of your progress.

p.object: What are you going to do?

chapter.p: Check that your project plan is up-to-date.
Produce several reports.
This module shows you how to:

ul.li: Click on the Project plan icon
From the Project menu, choose Team progress chart
Click on the dropdown list in the top left.

Click the print icon
A window opens

chapter.p: One task in this stage is to produce a report of the changes made in the key biblical terms.
In working on your translation you have identified and changed a number of key biblical terms.
Although you can’t use ParaTExt to write the report, it can produce of list of the terms that you have been dealing with and may need to include in your report.

p.object: What are you going to do?

chapter.p: In the Biblical terms tool you will filter on the book(s) that you want to include in your report. You will then save the list of the terms as a separate HTML file. You can also filter the list on any discussion notes you may have made.
This module shows you how to:

ul.li: Set the verses filter (for the books you have been working on).

secTitle.object: Save the list to a file

ul.li: Type a name for the file
Click on the ? on second column to sort on Rendering discussion notes.

secTitle.object: Find terms with text in the rendering description

ul.li: Click the arrow beside Find on the toolbar

Type the text to find
The list is filtered.
Save the list to HTML (as above).

chapter.p: The sixth stage of a translation project is finalizing for publication. This involves images, extra material, checking parallel passages and a number of other final checks.
This module shows you how to:

ul.li: Go to the verse where you want the illustration.
Type in the caption for the image (in your language). [1]
Type in a description of the image (in the language of the typesetter) [2]
Choose the width (either single column or page) [3]
If applicable, type in a verse range as an acceptable location [*]
Click Browse... then find figure/illustration file. [6]
Filter on a specific map number (e.g. [01])
Type a name for the file
Make sure there is an \h line

Type your introduction using the following markers:
\mt1
\is
\ip
Make sure all checks are ticked
Make sure all books to be published are chosen
Check any names on the list.
Redo the module FC: Formatting checks.

chapter.p: There are thousands of passage in the NT where either the same event is being described or where another verse is being quoted from the Old or New Testament. These verses need to be compared to make sure they are consistent.

Normally you will have translated and checked the text of both books with a consultant first. Though there are times that you will want to compare the other verses before you translate the second passage.

The parallel passages need to be consistent but they do not always need to be exactly the same. The Parallel Passages tool displays the various passages and highlights the text which is the same. But it is the meaning (not necessarily the form) that is important.

Normally you would make the comparisons made after you have translated the passage because you don’t want to be influenced by what could be a bad earlier translation. But there are times when you will want to be able to see a second passage while you are translating.

p.object: What you are going to do

ul.li: use the Parallel Passages tool to compare the verses.
use the check boxes to tell ParaTExt that you have checked the passages
open a quick reference window in ParaTExt to see another passage while you are translating.

chapter.p: This module shows you how to:
Configuration

ul.li: Navigate to the desired chapter and verse.

Tools > Parallel passages
A window is displayed showing a list and parallel passages.
Click the dropdown arrow beside the source text options

Choose as appropriate
The display changes.
Choose the filters as desired: [e.g. All references, Current book, Synoptic gospels]

Click on a line of references in the top pane.
The texts are displayed in the bottom pane.

section1.p: Text is shown in green when the text is exactly the same as in the other passage.
section1.blockquote: Text is shown in yellow when it has the same meaning (thought) even though it is not exactly the same as in the other passage.
If the text is green in Greek, then your text should also be the same.
section1.p: Normally, if the text is different in the Greek than it should be different in your text, but not always.

section1.blockquote: If two passage need to be the same, you should choose one (normally your later translation) and copy it over the other.

ul.li: Click blue link for the other text

section1.blockquote: Be careful when there is more than one verse. You don’t want to copy the \v.

ul.li: Click the check box beside the reference.

secTitle.object: Identify the passages which have been changed since they were marked as finished

ul.li: Change the passage filter to « Changed Text »

Click ab icon under the passage reference.
A comparison window is displayed in ParaTExt.
Return to the Parallel passages tool (using the task bar icons)
Click the check box to mark it as finished.

secTitle.object: Compare the text as you translate

ul.li:
Tools – Quick reference (Ctrl+q)
A window opens with the scroll group set to none.
Change the reference to the other passage.
Open you project a second time [File-Open project/resource]
Change the scroll group from [A] to None.
Change the reference to the other passage.

section1.p: Do you know what the colours and symbols mean? Match the symbols with their meanings for the upper and lower pane:

tr.td: No text or verse no. missing

types.comment: The following types are provided as pre-set examples. You may well want to create your own types that refer to one or more of these. You do that by typing in the names of the types in the types attribute of your type.
